Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Wisconsin proposes to build a prototype for an online, open Crowdsourcing Innovation Platform to develop roadmaps for the solution of pressing societal issues through articulation of long-term goals and germination of transformative research ideas and questions. A diverse group of doctoral students and postdocs will participate in a year-long workshop course, further developing their skills gained in a Summer Institute, learning about how the U.S. sets research priorities, and developing an innovative environment. In this environment, problem definition and rapid prototyping alternate, and groups of researchers and stakeholders constructively critique approaches. The platform will be a ?living network? that links ideas and people in a dynamic way to keep people intellectually and socially engaged. Through the process, a complex problem will continue to be divided into smaller sub-problems until they are amenable to solutions.

The next generation (the 'millennials') has already embraced that the future of scientific research will need to be more open, accessible, and democratic and that solutions to the pressing societal issues will come from making many small contributions to big projects collaboratively. This pilot project tests the hypothesis that crowdsourcing pressing societal problems to the global research community and stakeholders (i) meshes well with the value system of the next generation of researchers; (ii) lets us look at the problems simultaneously from different angles, and thus, in essence, increases the number of potential pathways to solutions, and (iii) increases the willingness to take risks and pursue novel research paths as large, complex problems are subdivided into smaller, more manageable problems by a group connected within a social network. If successful, it will provide a novel way to find solutions to the pressing societal problems of today's society. Additionally, through jointly exploring problem posing, the teams will gain confidence and the skills to tackle complex problems and uncover barriers to collaborating on complex, interdisciplinary problems that are of national and international importance. The potential for scalability and the transferability of this approach into other domains could contribute to a long-term change in how the research community interacts with itself and stakeholders to build pathways to solutions that respect social and behavioral constraints.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A critical step in solving today’s societal problems is the ability to pose problems in the first place. Over the duration of the project, we taught and further developed a conceptual framework that we called “from 0 to 2” to foster the search for optimal solutions to societal problems under societal, engineering, and scientific constraints through innovation by incremental advances. To solve pressing societal problems, we will need novel ideas (going from 0 to 1) that are implementable within societal constraints (going from 1 to 2). The project had two components that are described in the following.

(1) A seminar series on Collaborative Leadership and Grand Challenge Research that was kicked off on August 25 2016 with a 3-hour workshop and followed by thirteen 2-hour long seminars offered during the academic year 2016-17. Each seminar was led by an expert either from academia or the community. The seminar series included a self-assessment (the Hogan Management Focus Report) with subsequent debriefing and closed with tasking participants to put together their individual development plans. The topics of the year-long series were leadership to address global grand challenges; the innovative mindset/design thinking; Organizing research on “grand challenges": Transdisciplinary approaches; setting up teams for success; team leadership and facilitation; and community engagement as a strategy for addressing grand challenges. The seminar included panels with faculty and industry participants to address the issues of finding solutions to society’s most difficult problems; community engagement as a strategy for addressing grand challenges; and industry’s role in balancing challenges of social and economic value in research. Interspersed were practical topics, such as project management in research, innovation and development; visual strategy mapping; and stakeholder analysis, that would give participants tools to engage in problem solving.

(2) A year-long small discussion seminar that was attended by about 10 students in the fall and five students in the spring. The fall semester was focused on developing two topics that addressed pressing societal issues whose solutions would require collaborative work across diverse stakeholders across the affected community, government, and academia: food security and trafficking.  These topics were the launching point for the development of a more general framework in the spring semester. The focus in the spring semester shifted to inclusivity as many of the current problems involve diverse groups of stakeholders where lack of attention to diversity can become a barrier. We had significant discussions about how to develop online communities that would be respectful and effective, especially ones that are open to all but recognize different objectives of the participants. A major barrier to the use of social media was identified as the inability to easily cross social media platform to continue discussions with different stakeholder groups. For instance, platforms that cater to the research community are not inclusive of neighborhood communities as primary literature and the technical language of scientific communities quickly become a barrier.

The project was assessed. Although the sample sizes for the pre- and post-assessments were small, some trends emerged: Participating in a year-long intense project yielded an increase in confidence of conducting transdisciplinary and collaborative research that address important societal. This was also reflected in an increased willingness to take risks. However, there was a decline in the willingness to participate in research that relies on others. The experiences during the course of the program showed concerns: The current graduate education model does not encourage participation in research that addresses important societal problems. Although there was an increase in their enjoyment of working in teams and an increase in how well they felt they knew themselves, there were also frustrations with collaborative : Responses seem to indicate that students feel more comfortable in groups with similar personalities and don’t feel that their contributions are sufficiently acknowledged.
